bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 12, 1875

div1.p: Reed responds to Emilie Lawrence's teasing. He alludes to their wedding planned for the fall of 1876. He is beginning study of French and German.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 12, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Aug. 12th, 75.

div1.p:
If you have
received my last letter, you will
remember that I said that I
should, on Monday, expect a
sweet letter from you. Well,
sure enough the epistle came,
clad in the most lofty iro-
ny(?) and worthy of the
celebrated “John of Roa-
noke.” I almost expected to
see his signature attached
in full to the document-
You' dear little creature, you
will have your way; won't
you? That's right, my precious,
insist upon this always & I
will ever be happy to support
your efforts- I admire in-
dependence, possessing a
slight share of the same
myself. What's the use of ex-
isting, at all, if we can't
make our prescence felt-?
Power! 'Tis sweet to wield it!
A “fig” for timidity!- Forsooth,
what right had my mind, even
in sleep, to be entertaining
itself with visions of “fas-
cinating widows”? Did I for-
get that there is one (bless
her darling heart!) to whom
I am strictly accountable,
asleep or awake? Forgive
me, “my little B.”, this one time,
and I'll avoid all such
in the Future. And then, how
you did dive into metaphys-
ics! My! I had no idea that
you would detect the weak
points of my narrative &
play such sad havoc with
it. If it is really true, my
dear E., as you say, (and since
you say so, you'll excuse
me if I adopt your line of
argument,) that the mind, du-
ring sleep, is still busy
with the very thoughts that
absorbed its attention, du-
ring waking moments; if this be true,
I think it will unavoida-
bly follow that e're another
sun rises (if not already)
you'll imagine your name
changed to Lewter! How
delightful that would be!
Long life to Lewter & Lawrence!
By the way, I had another dream,
& this time, it was very pleasant,
but since my dreams seem
to serve as a target for your
choicest irony, I'll keep it
to myself, till I next see you.
Remember this -- I am deter-
mined to dream no more, till
after the fall of '76! After
that, I anticipate that my whole
life will be like a sweet
dream- With such a guardian
angel as you, my darling, by
my side, my life will, indeed,
be one continual state of dream-
y happiness -- no disagreeable
fancies flitting across my
mind- no! no! for an angel of
peace & joy will be with me!
I care not how fast the time
flies, for I know that, each mom-
ment spent, but brings me nearer
the dear creature whom I love
with all my heart! why talk,
my darling, about the “non-conge-
niality” of our dispositions? As
if, forsooth, such a thing could
be! Loving you as I do, I
have no fear whatever that
such will be; and when you
have learned to truly love, I
feel sure that all forebodings
will disappear. Hidden in my
heart of hearts, you will be
a sweet fountain giving light
& life to all things, and I shall
rest contented in your love.

Aug. 12th, 9 P.M.
I was interrupted in the writing
of my letter, by being compelled
to visit New York City, so that
my letter will not be mailed till
to-morrow morning, & will not reach
you till next Monday- I had a
very dreary day for my jour-
ney, inasmuch as it was rai-
ning almost continuously du-
ring the day, & as I was not pro-
vided with an umbrella, I got
a little moistened. When I re-
turned, this evening, I would have
gone on, at once, with my
writing, but Dr Byrne insisted
so strenuously that I should
make a call with him, that
I couldn't politely refuse.
We called at Lieutenant Mer-
cur's -- He doesn't happen to
be a bachelor like myself --
I met his wife, a pleasant
lady, & also his sister who
looks to be about 22, but by
no means pretty- You perceive
that although I am an “engag-
ed” gentleman, I still can tell
whether a lady is good-looking
or not. (I haven't seen anyone
with such a face as yours,
nor do I anticipate any such
rapturous visions, till I re-
turn, next fall.)

True to my word, I have be-
gun the study of French, and
oh! how I wish you were
present to teach me the
proper pronunciation -- It is
terribly difficult -- I'm afraid
you would have to scold
me mercilessly- I am de-
termined, however, to learn
the language & have, to-day,
finished my 4th lesson.
I shall begin German in a
few days, & thus study the two
languages conjointly- With these
& general literature, I can
manage to spend my time quite
profitably- I want to study 10
hours a day, besides taking
a plenty of exercise, so as
not to endanger my health.
I am so much behind the
times, & make so poor an ap-
pearance compared with the
majority of young gentleman
one meets in society, that
I feel as if I should not
spare a moment from my books.
But, for your sake, my precious E.,
I will take good care of my health.
As the page is about filled, I will say
“goodnight-”
div1.closer:
Ever, your fond,
and devoted Walter.
